ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

IMPROVEMENT OF DRAINAGE SYSTEM IN JOO CHIAT


    1. Mr Yeoh Ghim Seng asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether he is aware that the drainage system in the Joo Chiat Constituency is inadequate and whether and what steps he proposes to take to improve it.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, I agree with the hon. Member that the drainage system in Joo Chiat Constituency is inadequate. This situation has been made worse by indiscriminate and thoughtless dumping

Column: 563

of rubbish into the drains by some residents of the area. The lands in this area are generally low-lying and the drainage system rather antiquated. Overall radical improvement would be extremely costly and could only be carried out in conjunction with an urban renewal scheme. However, the Public Works Department is at present taking steps to carry out minor improvements to the main outlet drain running parallel to Haig Road and the subsidiary drains.

    The Department is also stepping up the making up of private streets in Joo Chiat. These works include the making up of earth drains into concrete ones. When these earth drains are reconstructed together with the other minor improvement works, the situation should improve. However, as my colleague, the Minister for Health, has pointed out the other day, the residents of the area must help to do their best to see that rubbish is not thrown into the drains.

Column: 563

CONVERSION OF JALAN BAHAR
INTO DUAL CARRIAGEWAY


    2. Mr Ho Kah Leong asked the Minister for Law and National Development when work will commence on the conversion of the reserved portion of Jalan Bahar in the Jurong Constituency into a dual carriageway.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (National Development Division) (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the existing single 24 feet wide carriageway of Jalan Bahar is sufficient to cater for the present volume of vehicular traffic. However, if in the future the need for a second carriageway arises, Jalan Bahar can be easily converted into a dual carriageway as all the necessary earthworks and kerbs have already been completed and only the metalling need be done.

Column: 564

UNAUTHORISED STRUCTURES
IN ALSAGOFF ESTATE


    3. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether he can confirm that the many structures, erected in Alsagoff Estate in the Kampong Kembangan Constituency and used as metal-works and saw-mills, are authorised structures.

    Mr Barker: Sir, most of the structures erected in Alsagoff Estate in Kampong Kembangan Constituency are unauthorised. Many of these structures are used as metal-works and saw-mills. Court action has been taken in respect of most of these structures, and the Chief Building Surveyor's Department will continue to take such action in this area which has become somewhat notorious for unauthorised structures.

Column: 564

RECONSTRUCTION OF
TEMPORARY DWELLING STRUCTURES
(Policy on submission of plans)


    4. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Law and National Development what is the policy of the Chief Building Surveyor's Department in regard to the submission of plans for the reconstruction of temporary dwelling structures in Alsagoff Estate.

    Mr Barker: The policy of the Chief Building Surveyor's Department with regard to the submission of plans for the reconstruction of temporary dwelling structures in Alsagoff Estate is the same as that for all other areas in the Republic. Applications for reconstruction of temporary dwelling structures are required to be submitted with the following documents:

    (1) the sketch plan for the proposed structure;

    (2) a temporary permit licence issued by the Chief Building Surveyor's Department to prove that the existing structure is an authorised one; and

Column: 565



    (3) either ground rent receipts and/or property tax receipts to prove ownership of the building.

    The construction or reconstruction of temporary structures without the Chief Building Surveyor's permission is an offence under the law. In order to contain the growth of unauthorised structures which finally become slums, the Chief Building Surveyor's Department is continually taking enforcement action against the persons responsible.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, can the Minister inform the House why some applicants are requested to submit architect's plans and the landowner's signature?

    Mr Barker: If the area of the building is over 700 square feet, then you need an architect's plan. If the applicant can satisfy the third requirement which I have referred to - ground rent receipts and/or property tax receipts - to prove ownership of the building as against ownership of the land, then you do not require the landowner's permission. Perhaps in the cases referred to by the hon. Member, the applicants could not produce any documentary evidence of ownership of the building. I say "perhaps", but I would be happy to look into and cause investigations to be made in respect of any particular case of which the hon. Member may come to know.

Column: 565

AGENCY FOR CONTROL AND EXPORT OF TROPICAL FISH


    5. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether he will consider establishing an agency under Government supervision to assist in the control and export of tropical fish.

    Mr Barker: Sir, the Government does not consider that there is any need to control or interfere with the export trade of tropical fish and the Government does not intend to establish an agency for such control. However, I

Column: 566

can assure the hon. Member for Punggol that the Primary Production Department is always in close contact with producers and exporters of tropical fish and, in fact, the Department renders considerable assistance to these exporters.

Column: 566

MEASURES TO STABILISE
PRICES OF PIGS AND POULTRY


    6. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the Minister for Law and National Development what measures are being taken by the Primary Production Department to stabilise the prices of pigs and poultry.

    Mr Barker: Whilst the prices of pigs and pork in the market have increased somewhat, the prices of poultry have not and are, in fact, slightly lower than normal. The increase of pork price is due to a temporary shortage of the supply of pigs from the farms consequent on the outbreak of swine fever in the latter part of last year. However, this shortage is only temporary and I expect the situation should improve when the young pigs at present in the farms have grown to marketable weight.

Column: 566

ELECTRICITY SUPPLY
(Complaints of voltage fluctuations)


    7. Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Public Utilities Board what steps will be taken to improve the electricity supply in areas where metal and wood works are carried out, as the operation of the heavy machinery used in those works often adversely affects the electricity supply to other consumers in the vicinity.

    Mr Barker: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Kampong Kembangan could indicate the specific localities where there are complaints of voltage fluctuations, the Public Utilities Board will carry out detailed investigations and take the necessary remedial action. There has been a general increase in

Column: 567

electricity demand in the hon. Member's constituency. The Electricity Department of the Public Utilities Board is examining the need for reinforcing the distribution system to cope with the power demand as well as to obviate the adverse effects of voltage fluctuations.

Column: 567

SURVEY INTO SINGAPORE'S MINERAL DEPOSITS POTENTIAL


    8. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Law and National Development whether any survey has been carried out into the mineral deposits potential of Singapore including its islands and foreshores, and what are the results; or whether such a survey will be carried out.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Law and National Development (Law Division) (Mr S. Ramaswamy) (for the Minister for Law and National Development): In 1950, a survey into the granite resources on Singapore and the surrounding islands was carried out for the purpose of determining its availability for construction purposes and road works. A report on this survey was published and presented to the then Legislative Assembly on 19th December, 1950. Since then, no other geological surveys have been carried out. If circumstances warrant it, Government will be prepared to undertake or authorise such survey into the mineral deposits potential of Singapore, its surrounding islands, foreshore and sea-bed.

Column: 567

REVISION OF WATER RATES FOR NON-COMMERCIAL
PURPOSES IN THOMSON


    9. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Law and National Development if he will ascertain from the Public Utilities Board whether the Board will take steps to revise water charges from the commercial to the domestic rate in respect of some consumers in the Thomson Constituency who are charged commercial rates but

Column: 568

who do not use the water for poultry-rearing or other commercial purposes, where this is genuinely found to be the case.

    Mr Barker: The answer is "Yes". If the premises are not used for poultry-rearing or other commercial purposes but exclusively for residential purposes, then the Public Utilities Board will charge the domestic water rate and that only.

Column: 568

RECRUITMENT OF MORE
FEMALE OFFICERS TO
PUBLIC SERVICE


    10. Madam Chan Choy Siong asked the Minister for Finance whether the intake into all grades of the public service recently has been of male officers mainly, and if he will consider taking steps to promote the recruitment of more female officers to the service.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not true that the intake into all grades of the public service recently has been mainly male officers. For instance, most appointments as nurses and nursing assistants are women, More than 60 per cent of the teachers recruited in 1967 were women. On the other hand, some posts are unsuitable for women, for instance, combat troops, night watchmen and lighthouse keepers. Male and female candidates are considered strictly on their suitability for the posts concerned. For the first half of this year, 955 female candidates were offered appointment out of a total recruitment of 2,849.

    As regards the second part of the question, it would be wrong to give preference to women in recruitment to the public service. The P.A.P. Government has accepted that women are equal to men; it has not accepted that they are more equal.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Sir, I would like to ask two supplementary questions. First,

Column: 569

according to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance, the Government has no bias against females in recruitment to the public service. He has pointed out that in cases like nurses or nursing assistants and teachers -

    Mr Speaker: Madam Chan, can you get to your supplementary question without repeating what Mr Tang has said?

    Madam Chan Choy Siong(In Mandarin): My first supplementary is this. Does the Parliamentary Secretary agree that in other departments many female applicants have been rejected?

    The second question is, does the Parliamentary Secretary acknowledge that all members in the Public Service Commission are males and whether this fact would not lead to prejudice and bias against females?

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, as regards the first question, I can only repeat what I have said, that there is no prejudice against women and that candidates are considered strictly on their suitability for the posts concerned.

    As to the second question, I am afraid I cannot accept the hon. Member's contention that the P.S.C. is biased against females. As regards membership of the P.S.C., perhaps if a suitable female candidate could be found, I am sure the President would be delighted to appoint her.

Column: 569

EMPLOYMENT BILL


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [10th July. 1968], "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Question again proposed.

3.47 p.m.

    Mr Lim Soo Peng (Havelock): Mr Speaker, Sir, clause 47 as it stands in the Bill is a very good one. It gives discretion to the employer to pay a bonus to his employees, the amount varying from employee to employee,

Column: 570

depending upon their performance and productivity. At present, the bonus provision in collective agreements applies equally to all employees. Whether a person is a good worker or a bad worker, he gets the same bonus. In other words, a good worker is penalised in that he gets the same reward in the form of bonus as another who is inefficient and unproductive. However, there are some genuine misgivings on this provision, as not all employers are enlightened employers. Some employers may take advantage of this provision and give no bonus or ex-gratia payment whatsoever. This should not be the case if they make a profit. To allay the fears of the workers that they might be deprived of a bonus, the amendment to be moved by the Member for Bukit Ho Swee is a reasonable one and should be supported. It makes the payment of bonus negotiable up to one month's wages, and any payment above one month's wages is at the discretion of the employer. In this manner, bonus can still be used as an incentive for higher productivity or as a reward for good performance.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the standardisation of working hours at 44 hours a week as contained in clause 39 is a very good provision. It does away with the distinction between a white-collar and a blue-collar worker. The limitation of overtime work will help to create more needed jobs for our people. However, in view of the shortage of skilled workers in special trades, this provision has to be applied intelligently. It may not be possible to limit overtime work to 48 hours a month in all cases. I am glad to note that this has been recognised and is provided for in sub-clause (4) of clause 39. As this law is new in more respects than one, we must tread cautiously. We must be magnanimous. We must always be willing to listen and always ready to change. With an open mind and flexibility, we must entertain and process all reactions to this legislation, from the workers and trade unions to the employers and the public. Our future will, in fact, be more dependent on the goodwill and understanding

Column: 571

of all citizens in operating this Bill than on the clauses contained therein. I feel that if given a fair trial, this Bill will undoubtedly succeed.

3.52 p.m.

    Mr Lim Cheng Lock (Kampong Kapor): Mr Speaker, Sir, if this Bill had been called our survival or salvation Bill, it would have been less controversial and would have been more receptive. A great deal of misapprehension, fears and doubts on the provisions of the Employment Bill were created in the minds of our working citizens even before this Bill was introduced in this House. True, it was openly admitted that there had been consultations and discussions between the Government, N.T.U.C, leaders and employers, and in discussions of this nature it is not possible to contain and confine the contents of the discussions. But the allegations and rumours concerning the provisions of the Bill, which had been circulated to the public prior to the introduction of the Bill in this House and even after its introduction in this House, have, I feel, caused much harm, particularly as to the real purpose and intent which this Bill is designed to do.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, rumours, however unbelievable, have their source of origin. I feel it will be worth the while for the Government to inquire whether there had been any unauthorised leakage of information or intentions in regard to the Employment Bill. It is unwise to spread rumours, more so in this House. If you would allow me, Mr Speaker, Sir, to cite one point which was alleged to be a provision in this Bill just to illustrate how harmful these rumours were. The rumour was that married women, whose husbands are employed, would not be permitted to work in order to create more jobs for the unemployed. Such a rumour in the prevailing situation would be difficult to disbelieve. Nevertheless, as I say it, it had a very harmful effect on the people.

Column: 572



    In order to appreciate the intent of this Bill, which is essential and vital to accelerate economic growth and expansion so that more jobs can be created, it is absolutely necessary, first, to remove those doubts and fears and restore the confidence of the workers in the pro-labour policy which the Government has always pursued and practised, so that the implementation of this Bill would have a fair chance of success.

    I feel it is absurd to suggest that the leaders of the Government have all of a sudden turned anti-labour and taken sides with the employers. What could they benefit at this stage of their political career and what benefit could the country gain from a weak labour force and a beaten N.T.U.C.? There has been in the past a total lack of discipline in the labour force. Now is the time for all good trade union leaders in the Republic to be honest and courageous enough to enforce strict discipline among the members, particularly those who are malingerers, lazy, inefficient and unproductive workers. They should stop giving them protection. By and large, our citizen workers are a hard-working lot and if only our trade union leaders will stop giving protection and cover to this very small percentage of malingerers and unproductive workers, we will no doubt achieve a much healthier situation.

    The existing Labour Ordinance, the Clerks Employment Ordinance and the Shop Assistants Employment Ordinance, which became law more than 10 years ago, were enacted against a different background and in different circumstances. They are all now outdated and no longer serve the needs of the people at present and for the future.

    With the introduction of the Employment Bill as well as the Industrial Relations (Amendment) Bill and the Central Provident Fund (Amendment) Bill, a new era in the employer and employee relationship will emerge. The intent of the Employment Bill is to secure on a firm and sound basis a healthy, disciplined and competitive labour force in the Republic which will ensure our continued survival. It is

Column: 573

designed to standardise and regulate the working conditions of all workers regardless of whether they are white-collar or blue-collar workers or shop assistants. It seeks to remove malpractices and restrictive practices which make enforcement and maintenance of discipline difficult and, therefore, hinder economic growth. If we are to increase productivity, there must be discipline in our labour force. Without discipline there can be no efficiency, and without efficiency it is not possible to increase productivity.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it has often been said that the island of Singapore has no natural resources of its own and that we owe our living to the ingenuity and skill of our people. If we are to meet the challenges of the l970s, if we are to continue living as a people with an identity, if we are to make progress, then we must be prepared to make sacrifices now to ensure our survival as a nation.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not propose to go into the controversial provisions of the Bill in detail, as many other Members have already dealt with them. There will be ample opportunity to do so when we are in the Committee stage. But I would like to touch on Part XI, consisting of clauses 109 to 112 which incorporate changes to give Government a measure of control over the hiring of workers. In particular I refer to clause 112 which empowers the Minister to make regulations to control the engagement of employees by employers. On this I would sound a note of caution to the Minister and his Ministry. Present indications are that the machinery of the Employment Exchange is totally inadequate and it is not efficient enough to cope with additional work. This provision should not be implemented until the machinery of the Employment Exchange is adequately geared to its new task. There should be consultation with employers and the N.T.U.C, on the proposed regulations so as to ensure that their implementation does not impede efficiency and retard

Column: 574

employers from recruiting the right type of persons they require in the shortest possible time.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, this Bill in its present form is unacceptable without amendments. Several amendments have already been tabled by the Minister for Labour and the Member for Bukit Ho Swee and I urge that these amendments should be seriously considered.

    While the Employment Bill updates the working conditions of workers in the private commercial sector, Government should not overlook updating similar working conditions in the public sector. Both are complementary and must be implemented concurrently if we are to achieve results. Government should also expeditiously consider and release the Report of the Salaries Commission and to take steps to remedy and correct any anomalies so as to ensure also an efficient, productive and contented civil service in the Republic. Mr Speaker, Sir, I support this Bill with amendments.

3.04 p.m.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, allow me to speak on some of the provisions in this Bill. I look forward to the amendment of some of the provisions therein, especially as some of my colleagues have already tabled amendments to certain clauses in the Bill. When it comes to the Committee stage, I would like to move to amend the amendments proposed by my colleagues.

    First, I refer to the spirit of this Bill and the mood and reaction of the people to the Bill.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the masses have been gravely concerned since the Employment Bill was read the First time in this House. Many groups of people, either in the streets or in the coffee shops, have gathered and discussed the contents of the Bill. At the same time, another class of people living in luxury flats gather together in their offices and discuss the Bill. They rack their brains over it. Obviously, this class of people represent the

Column: 575

employers. They appear quite satisfied with this Bill so far because we have not heard any opposition to it from them.

    The only people who are not happy about this Bill are the working class. They have discussed its contents in coffee shops, in the streets and many other places. Many of the provisions in the Bill are the same as those contained in the original labour laws. However, there are some new provisions which will affect their future livelihood and their family. As a result, they are grumbling and have complained that the Government is trying to change its attitude towards them and that it has changed its consistent stand on labour. Some of them have even gone to the extent of saying that because there is only one party in Parliament, it can do things arbitrarily without regard to anybody's opinions. This is a very good opportunity to be made use of by the Barisan Sosialis and others like them.

    If we examine carefully the arguments of these people and assess them against the spirit and content of this Bill, we will find that there is a certain degree of discontent among some of the people. We will also realise that some of the provisions should not have been included in the Bill at all, or at least they should be amended in the process of debate. Viewed this way, I regret to say that the contents of this Bill are entirely divorced from the realities of present-day society. Those who drafted this Bill have not gone among the people to assess the living conditions of the general masses.

    If it is said that the Bill gives the correct definitions for reward, efficiency, effort, productivity, then we are neglecting the common interests between labour-cum-consumer on the one hand and the employer on the other. This neglect arises because the long-term interests of the employer depend on a large consumer market. This market in turn depends on the price of goods and on whether the people have the means to buy such goods. At the same time, in order to increase production, there must be a demand for

Column: 576

them. The fact remains that labour-cum-consumers do not have the money to buy them.

    I believe all loyal citizens will do their best to meet the challenge of the 1970s. The solution cannot be dependent on merely passing a Bill, or on any passive way of readjustment to the distribution of wealth, because that is not enough. We must take all measures to maintain our economic prosperity for the long-term stability of Singapore and to strengthen our economy.

    It is important also to prevent any grave repercussions in our society. When people are desperate, they cannot contribute anything worth while to the country. Therefore, we must pursue our scientific studies actively in order to promote our economic progress. We must study the potential effects that science and technology can play in our economic development and stability so that we may step into a new era of industrialisation in which there will be innovations and more employment opportunities. It is necessary to have innovations and modern techniques of manufacturing in order to meet the increased needs of the consumers. There should also be improvement in the techniques of production. There should be modern equipment and co-operation between employers and employees in order to increase productivity.

    Labour's demand for wage increases and fringe benefits is usually a stimulant to economic progress. In other words, this demand will also stimulate technical progress. In this present age, trade unionists realise that wage increases without increased productivity will result in a rise in the prices of goods and a reduction in the number of people employed. Therefore, they try to get fringe benefits for the workers. The present Employment Bill seeks to take some of these away. This is contrary to the concept of industrial psychology and is also against the mood of the workers. It is a retrogressive act.

Column: 577



    I believe most people can understand the labour policy of our Government. The original policy of bias towards labour will not be changed. Undoubtedly, as an efficient Government with long-term political objectives, it will preserve its pro- labour policy. The enactment of the Employment Bill into law is only a change of technique. The basic pro-labour policy of our Government will never change. What can be changed is the technique in order to meet the requirements of the nation and the changing situation.

    As democratic socialists, the first step for us is to seek independence and to raise productivity. Unless we can concurrently increase national productivity, we will not have a fair, just and equal society for the people. It is therefore necessary to get a larger market. We must industrialise in order to improve the livelihood of our people. Now that Singapore is an independent country, we can depend only on our human resources. We have to carry out the great tasks of our country. The people should meet the challenge of this age and march forward in unity. The source of economic strength cannot be separated from our resources.

    Even with natural and human resources, we cannot ensure our country's prosperity and progress. There should be some catalyst to promote economic progress. One mode of bringing this about is by way of legislation. The introduction of the Employment Bill can be said to have come from the consideration of trying to ensure full-scale economic prosperity.

    The Minister for Labour explained the true purpose of this Bill in Parliament the other day. After 1971, the economic welfare and survival of Singapore lies in the hands of our people. In a small island like Singapore, we cannot plant cotton or other crops or foodstuffs but we have to maintain the livelihood of many people. One square mile in Singapore will have to support 8,000 Singaporeans. So a stagnant economy will mean starvation.

Column: 578

This Bill is introduced so as to meet our political and defence requirements and so that the people can adjust themselves to face the new situation when the British troops are withdrawn. I support the views of the Minister for Labour.

    The introduction of the Employment Bill does not mean that the Government has already adopted a policy of suppression of the workers. Certain provisions in the Bill have, on the other hand, caused some anxiety among the workers. On the surface, the provisions can easily be construed to be anti-labour or contrary to the Government's policy of bias towards labour, because, to a certain degree, these provisions will adversely affect the future livelihood of the people. For this reason, I am of the view that if the Government can be enlightened enough to accept certain amendments tabled by my colleagues, it will still be possible to avert any wrong impression gained by some people about the Government.

    The President in his speech in May mentioned certain Bills which reflected the general mood, thought and spirit of our people. He also exhorted the Government and Members of Parliament to give a lead in the thinking and feeling in the country. In view of these considerations, I hope Government will accept the amendment which will be moved by the Member for Bukit Ho Swee (who is also the Secretary-General of the National Trades Union Congress) to clause 15. If the Government does not accept the amendment, it will have to consider the consequences that will follow. If this clause is passed as it now stands, the Government will not achieve any good results. On the contrary, it will achieve the opposite of that which the clause intends, because there will be quite a number of people who will be retiring prematurely.

    The purpose of this Bill is to provide more jobs for the unemployed, but its enactment into law will mean driving more people into unemployment. If these people are unemployed when they

Column: 579

are forced to retire, what can they do thereafter? if they want to be non-criminal types, they may resort to becoming hawkers or pirate taxi drivers. Does the Government wish to see more hawkers appearing and more pirate taxis running on the roads? Clause 15 as it appears in the Bill must not therefore be passed into law.
